unnormalised: ## The Kota Dream: How I Almost Cracked the IIT
normalised: It all started after my Class tenth boards. Like every other science student in my Patna neighborhood, the I-I-T dream was planted firmly in my head. My parents, bless their souls, thought a good coaching center was the key. "Kota is the place, beta," my father declared, having read endless articles about A-I-R one, A-I-R two, and the like.

unnormalised: It all started after my Class 10th boards. Like every other science student in my Patna neighborhood, the IIT dream was planted firmly in my head. My parents, bless their souls, thought a good coaching center was the key. "Kota is the place, beta," my father declared, having read endless articles about AIR 1, AIR 2, and the like.
normalised: So, off I went to Kota, Rajasthan. My parents enrolled me in 'Resonance Classes', paying a hefty sum of rupee one point five lakh for the year. The sheer volume of students was overwhelming. Each batch had about two hundred to two hundred and fifty students. The classes started at eight AM sharp, with back-to-back lectures on Physics, Chemistry, and Maths. We barely had time to breathe, let alone understand what was being taught.

unnormalised: So, off I went to Kota, Rajasthan. My parents enrolled me in 'Resonance Classes', paying a hefty sum of Rs. 1.5 lakh for the year. The sheer volume of students was overwhelming. Each batch had about 200-250 students. The classes started at 8:00 AM sharp, with back-to-back lectures on Physics, Chemistry, and Maths. We barely had time to breathe, let alone understand what was being taught.
normalised: The teachers, mostly I-I-T graduates themselves, were brilliant but detached. They flew through the syllabus, solving complex problems in seconds. We, on the other hand, were struggling to keep up. The daily homework was a mountain – easily fifty to sixty problems per subject. Sleepless nights became the norm. My room became a mess of textbooks, notes, and half-eaten Maggi packets.

I remember one Physics test where I scored just twenty divided by one hundred and twenty. It was crushing. Doubts began to creep in. Was I cut out for this?

unnormalised: Finally, the D-day arrived. I appeared for the JEE Main exam on 08/04/2018. The paper was tough. I attempted as many questions as I could, but I knew I hadn't done my best. The results came out a few weeks later. I had scored 190 marks. Not enough to get into IIT.
normalised: Looking back, I don't regret my time in Kota. It was a valuable learning experience, even though I didn't crack the I-I-T. I learned the importance of hard work, discipline, and perseverance. And I realized that there are many paths to success, not just one. I ended up pursuing my B.S.C. in Computer Science from a college in Delhi, and I'm doing just fine. Perhaps coaching isn't for everyone.
